page.lettertext:
fol.271r
[15]
92 8 Au
g
To my L Trea
s
May it please your good L. Wheras her
M
tie
hath eftsoons written in
e case
of
Coronel Sonoy
, and your L. in your last
at concerned his affaires, re
q
red
me to bring it to some final c
o
clusion: I have don[e] in
at respect for
e Coronels
adv
a
tage w
at
was possible for me. But for as muche as his demaundes are
not all of one qualitie, and this people most unwilling to shewe him any
kinde of favour, I have bin forced for his benefit to temporise in my dealing,
to solicite men in privat, to part his suite into divers motions, and to observe
some other courses w
ch
those
at are his factours did thinck behoofull to c
o
tinue.
For this occasion I could not write yow any resolut answear about his busines
and to put you to
e trouble of understanding all
e causes of those delayes
at
were used, considering M
r
Sonoy was well informed by his friendes, I thought
it not c
o
veni
e
t. But nowe
at all is effected,
at I am able to obtene, it may
please your L. to be certified,
at maters stande in these termes, That of
e
Coronels whole demaunde, amounting almost to 5000
ll
sterling, there is
onely payed unto him 80
ll
for certaine gonne powder, w
ch
he had left of his owne
in
e towne of
Medemblick
: and 500
ll
sterling more, for
at he was indebted to
e inhabit
a
ts of
e towne, w
ch
I have gotte to be discharged. But wholy
against
e heare, and w
t
very muche c
o
tention in my conference w
t
them.
And for that w
ch
is remaining of
e summe afore m
e
tioned, w
ch
is due for arrie-
rages of divers intertenment
, I can gette no other answear, albeit I have
used very speciall endevours, but
at he shall be so c
o
sidered as
e rest of their
creditours: w
ch
is so sette downe at length in their booke of resolutions, wherof
they have sent me an autentical extract, and
e transcript in Frenche shall
be joined w
t
this l
re
, as I have also sent a copie to
e Coronel himselfe.
But all their awnswear in
at behalfe is no better in effect then a c
u
ning
deniall. For if they were inclined to any e
q
tie in his suite, they know
his case doth differ muche from
e most of
e rest, to whome
e co
u
try is
indebted. For when
y
they made their c
o
position he was actual govern
r
of
e towne of Medemblick, and they c
o
tracted plainely w
t
him
at ether
he should c
o
tinue as governo
r
in
e place, or have an honorable discharge,
and c
o
tentm
t
w
t
reason for all his services forepast. Whereupon I have
insisted,
at although they do p
r
tend
e w
a
t of means and habilitie to pay
e
summes
at he demaundes, yet it is a matter in their power, and a part of
their coven
a
t, to restore him to his governm
t
. The replie
at they
make, is but a dallieng abuse, by
vertinge
e sense of a plaine c
o
position.
For they say they are but bounde to c
o
tent him w
t
reason: and they thinck
he ought to take it for a reasonable contentm
t
, in that they promise to
intreate him as
e rest of their creditours. W
ch
in effect is no better, but
fol.271v
p
nt
ly to leese
e benefit of his gouvernm
t
, and to have as muche as not
[hing]
for his recompense heereafter: and so I have not failed to lette them
understand. But to impart to your L. my privat c
o
ceat, though
they themselves will not signifie
e misterie of their meaning in this
twart kinde of dealing, yet they make it very manifest by
e course
of their doinges, and by
e cleerenes of their speeches in
e causes of
some others. For thus they are
suaded, and nothing can be said,
at
will dissuade them from it, That when my
L. of Leycester
was
chosen to this governm
t
, he had a p
nt
intention, to make a c
o
quest of
e co
u
try, and
at divers suche as M
r
Sonoy did not onely w
at
they could to
second his dessignes, but were
e principal plotters of those intended
alterations
at were essayed in divers townes. And this opinion of
their disloyaltie is rooted so deeply in a number of this nation,
at
though they seeme in open shewe, not to seeke to revenge it, they will
grieve
e parties underhand, by all
e meanes they can devise.
Of
e occur
e
ces at
e Campe, I can not, being heere, make a
fitte report: and because I do attend upon her M
ties
pleasure,about
e sending for
e companies, I can not as I would c
o
veniently goe thither
For
e states residing heere, w
t
whome I must negotiat in affaires of
at nature, if I should be at
e Campe, w
t
e bringing thither of my l
re
s,
and my returning hither againe, there would be
adv
e
ture a greater
losse of time then her M
tie
would like. Touching
at w
ch
was advertised
from
e
Councel of Estate
,
at certaine forces of
e Enemy were marched
out of
Brabant
, and passed
e Maese, I knowe not whereupon it came, bu
[t]
they speake no more of it. For w
ch
e Englishe c
o
panies c
o
tinue still
in garrison, and
Count Maurice
proceedeth in
e siege of
Coevoer
[den]
having gained already
e bourgh before
e Castell, and beaten dow
[n]
a great part of
e castell it self: wherby his hope is er be long to
[.]
at woorke unto an ende. Upon secret intelligence from
certaine in
Groeninghen
at sins
Stenwick
was taken
e chiefe w
t
in
[the]
towne are devided among themselves, of w
ch
some are desirous to tre
[.]
these co
u
tries, upon hope of obtening more equal conditions,
e states
[have]
written to
e towne a very kind l
re
, w
ch
is sent by a trumpet from
e
[camp]
whose returne is expected w
t
in five or six daies.
And thus I tak
[e my]
humble leave. From
e Hage. Au
g
8 1592.
